pages.page: WOMEN AND THE VOTE: CENTENNIAL CALENDAR

The Road to the Vote On August 26, 1920, the 19th Amendment was enacted, adding one word to the Constitution—“The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex.” (bold face added) This calendar brings to life the long history of the struggle for women’s suffrage.* It honors the many hundreds of thousands of women who labored to extend the basic right to vote in the United States to women. As we mark this centennial, we remember also that the history of women’s suffrage in the United States begins even longer ago. Some trace it to the inspiration of the women of the Seneca and other Indian nations who owned property and voted, and who influenced the thinking of the early suffragists who gathered at Seneca Falls in 1848. Some look to the US Constitution which, in 1789, left to the states the right to determine the requirements for voting. This eighteen-month calendar extends from July 2019 to December 2020. The months from July through December 2019 contain themes and dates relating to the late 18th and 19th centuries. January through December 2020 focus on the events and people of the 20th century as well as selected dates from the 19th century. To be certain, the enactment of the 19th Amendment in 1920 did not mark the end of the story. The work to extend suffrage continued throughout the 20th century, as constitutional amendments, laws, and court decisions added new categories of voters to the rolls (e.g., persons 18–21, residents of Washington, DC, overseas military personnel) and addressed barriers (e.g. poll taxes) that kept many women—and men—from exercising their constitutional right to vote. The history of women’s struggle for the vote is also intertwined with struggles for the right to vote for African Americans, the poor, immigrants, Hispanics, American Indians, and others. It has been a history marked by successes and setbacks, cooperation as well as conflict, sexism as well as racism. This story of universal suffrage is still unfolding. Despite progress, voter suppression efforts are alive and well, interfering with the ability of all citizens to exercise their fundamental right to vote. As suffragist Crystal Eastman reminded her sisters following the passage of the 19th Amendment, “Now we can begin.” * From the Latin word suffragium, meaning the right to vote.

JULY 2019 The 1800s give rise to activism addressing emancipation, suffrage and other basic human rights. In Seneca Falls, at the First Woman’s Rights Convention, organizers Mott and Stanton and attendees — including Frederick Douglass, a lifelong defender of women’s rights (below)––sign the Declaration of Sentiments promoting women’s rights. In the following years, activists convene and form multiple national organizations to press for suffrage over the next 70 years. SEPTEMBER 2019 The 15th Amendment, ratified on February 3, 1870, prohibits federal and state governments from denying citizens the right to vote due to “race, color, or previous condition of servitude.” Its passage is followed by Reconstruction and a period of voter suppression that uses poll taxes, literacy tests, violence, and other means. It takes nearly 100 years for poll taxes to be prohibited by the 24th Amendment and the sweeping reforms of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 that break down many state and local legal barriers to voting by African American men and women (below). OCTOBER 2019 NAACP’s magazine, The Crisis, a strong supporter of women’s suffrage, commemorates a meeting 50 years earlier between Sojourner Truth and President Lincoln in a special 1915 edition on suffrage (above). Sojourner Truth, born a slave, is a skilled orator, passionate abolitionist, and proponent of suffrage for women and black men. Harriet Tubman (below), also born a slave, supports hundreds escaping north from slavery, serves as a scout, spy, and nurse for the Union Army, and is an advocate for women’s suffrage and rights in her later years. JANUARY 2020 Borrowing tactics from more militant British “Suffragettes,” the National Woman’s Party, led by Alice Paul and Lucy Burns, brings the protest to the White House gates. Throughout a 21⁄2-year-long vigil, thousands of women stand as Silent Sentinels, light a watchfire (below), and hold signs challenging the President to support suffrage and endorse a constitutional amendment. The vigil only ends on June 4, 1919, when Congress passes a proposed amendment to extend the vote to women and focus shifts from the federal level to the states to ensure ratification. FEBRUARY 2020 In the late 19th century, black women found clubs focusing on the welfare of their communities, education, and other social issues including suffrage. In 1896, two major clubs merge to form the first truly national organization of black women — the National Association of Colored Women (NACW). Mary Church Terrell is its first President (above) and “Lifting As We Climb” its motto. With the leadership of Harriet Tubman (2nd row, 6th from right), Margaret Washington, Fannie Barrier Williams and others, the NACW grows to 50,000 members and 1,000 clubs nationwide by 1914. Mary McLeod Bethune is elected President in 1924. MARCH 2020 To reinvigorate the suffrage movement, the National American Woman Suffrage Association, under Alice Paul’s leadership, organizes the first political parade in Washington, DC, on the day before President Wilson’s inauguration. Thousands of women from across the country march, including state delegates, teachers, women who hike from New York, and representatives from other countries. As a protest against the exclusion of black women, Ida B. Wells joins the Illinois delegation (below, right). Terrell represents NACW and marches with Delta Sigma Theta in their first public act. In 1953, at the age of 90, she marches with pickets to integrate Washington. DC lunch counters. JUNE 2020 The origins of the National Woman’s Party (NWP) date from 1912, when Alice Paul and Lucy Burns, young Americans schooled in the militant tactics of British suffragism, are appointed to NAWSA’s Congressional Committee. They inject more militancy into the American campaign and shift attention away from state voting rights toward a federal suffrage amendment. The NWP is formed at a June 5–7, 1916, meeting of the Congressional Union in Chicago. Note: NAWSA badge from 1905 (below) honors Sacagawea as first woman to vote in America. JULY 2020 Many of the thousands of suffragists who picket at the White House and elsewhere are harassed, insulted, arrested, and otherwise unjustly treated by local and federal authorities. Lucy Burns (below, center) is among those who are imprisoned and force-fed when she goes on a hunger strike. On November 14, 1917, in what is known as the “Night of Terror,” many suffragists are brutally tortured and abused in the jail where they are being held. AUGUST 2020 After the Tennessee legislature passes the 19th Amendment by a single vote, Alice Paul, on the balcony of the headquarters of the National Woman’s Party in DC, unfurls a banner with 36 stars; the 36th star represents Tennessee, the 36th and last state necessary for ratification. DECEMBER 2020 Even with the successful passage of the 19th Amendment, suffragists are clear that they have not accomplished everything needed for women to be full participants in American democracy. Alice Paul immediately begins work on the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA). Even 100 years later, Virginia fails in 2019 by a single vote to pass the ERA as the 38th state needed for ratification; many women and men face continuing forms of voter suppression; and, as recently as 2018, 37.5 million women who are citizens are not registered to vote. The work continues. SUNDAY MONDAY TUESDAY WEDNESDAY THURSDAY FRIDAY SATURDAY “There is a danger that because of a great victory women will believe their whole struggle for independence ended.
